entry.value:
[{"id":"ST-786","entityId":"64-9541","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"786"},{"name":"summary","value":"Find a way to get logger names and levels in the syslog-managed log file"},{"name":"description","value":"
When the spdlog logger is configured to use the syslog log sink class, it discards the logger name, which does not appear in the resulting log file.

The logger names are a very important source of diagnostic information. I think it is worth the time to figure out some way, no matter how ugly it may be, to get the logger names into the syslog file.

We are already using the spdlog-provided mechanism for specifying the content of every log line, and we are telling it to include the logger name. spdlog must have code that bypasses this configuration when using the syslog sink. Since we don't want to change the spdlog code itself, we will probably have to do something ugly like explicitly prepending the logger name to the log string. I hope there is another hook in the spdlog API that gives us an opportunity to do so.


Edit: Now that I have the syslog destination running on my machine, I see that the log level also does not appear in the log file. If anything, this is even more important than the logger name. I really need both of them to appear in the log file.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1535640102924"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535729428924"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"0"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Feature"],"valueId":["Feature"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-780","entityId":"64-9520","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"780"},{"name":"summary","value":"Control.log not being written to."},{"name":"description","value":"
Tim Crews asked me to delete the control log this morning (ST-772), which I did. I just noticed it is empty. Nothing is being written to the control log today. (based on Tim's comments from ST-772 this has been going on since at least yesterday.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1535560909655"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535650561557"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"resolved","value":"1535567944042"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"14"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-772","type":"Relates","role":"relates to"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Major"],"valueId":["Major"],"color":{"bg":"#ffee9c","fg":"#b45f06"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Bug"],"valueId":["Bug"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Obsolete"],"valueId":["Obsolete"],"color":{"bg":"#b7e281","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tcrews","fullName":"Tim Crews"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null},{"name":"attachments","value":[{"value":"control.log","id":"70-8137","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/control.log?file=70-8137&c=true"},{"value":"LSMSettings.ini","id":"70-8138","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/LSMSettings.ini?file=70-8138&c=true"}]}],"comment":[{"id":"69-17402","author":"Miles","authorFullName":"Miles McNerney","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Here's the LSMSettings.ini, I'd think we'd get some debug messages anyway



[LogLevel]
default = debug
camera = trace
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535561131850,"updated":1535561174844,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17403","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Miles McNerney Tim Crews does ST-772 (weird JSON & BIN not matching error message) a symptom of this issue?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535561260442,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17407","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
No, ST-772 is definitely not related to this issue.

Jerry, the log file is no longer located at /var/opt/uls-control/control.log. It is located at /var/log/uls-control.log.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535562197371,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17410","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
We should stop a "control.log" from being made @ /var/opt/uls-control then.

I will make a note to start using the /var/log/uls-control.log
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535562411529,"updated":1535561260442,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17412","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I agree; I will look into that.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563315415,"updated":1535562197371,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17413","author":"Miles","authorFullName":"Miles McNerney","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
There's a uls-control.log at that location w/data. But it's not showing up in the GUI
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563356209,"updated":1535561131834,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17414","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Ah, the LSM needs to be updated with this new location. The tricky part is, the destination of the log file is configurable at run-time (based on the [LogDestination] settings in LSMSettings.ini), and the LSM currently has no way of knowing that configuration.

But if the default configuration (controlled by the .deb package installer) is to log to the syslog (/var/log/uls-control.log), it seems that the LSM default should be to use that same location.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563632611,"updated":1535563315415,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17415","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Once the /var/opt/uls-control/control.log is no longer being generated and this issue is toggled to fixed, I will verify the fix and close it out. Downgrading to Major from Release Critical.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535563862838,"updated":1535562411529,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17420","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I changed the code so it does not open control.log if the [LogDestinations] section does not specify "file" for any logger. This will be the case for the default installation (e.g. in Lab 3). So you shouldn't see /var/opt/uls-control/control.log anymore.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535567936305,"updated":1535563632611,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17421","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I just looked at ULTRA-lab3 and the LogDestination is set to syslog. Should I just change it back to file?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535568628091,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17422","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I certainly prefer the file logging because the resulting logs include logger names. But I guess I need to learn to live with what syslog provides, since that is what we'll be getting from fielded installations.

At any rate, don't change it back to file until Jerry has had a chance to verify my 11:38 change, otherwise he will still see a control.log file and think my change didn't work.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535568928814,"updated":1535567936289,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17426","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
OK
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535569791843,"updated":1535568628091,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17447","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Aaron Jones, since the syslog destination will be the production configuration, I think we should leave it that way in Lab 3 and Paradise. But I also think it is important to have the logger names in the log file (my only reason for preferring the "file" destination to the "syslog" destination). So I created ST-786.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535640190097,"updated":1535568928799,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17453","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-780","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Obsolete due to ST-786.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535650561557,"updated":1535563862838,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-242","entityId":"64-7244","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"242"},{"name":"summary","value":"Resume Broken"},{"name":"description","value":"
Noticed today on Sabretooth SabretoothInst-6.03.59.01 2017.12.22.0336.exe

Imported & ran the attached PDF

10:41:00 - Start job. Everything seems to run normal. Laser is engraving (all good)

10:45:00 - Pause job. Job pauses (takes about 3 clicks to get job to pause), XY returns home (good)

10:48:00 - Resume job attempted. Click resume job but job does not resume. First message (001.png) is "recent settings require job to be restarted" - no changes were made. Job was simply paused then resume was attempted. Clicked resume again (002.png) and got message unable to pause job (which actually makes sense due to the fact the job has been lost at this point the job must be restarted to be able to be paused again.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1513965217997"},{"name":"updated","value":"1515101216770"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"resolved","value":"1514500466871"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"7"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-223","type":"Relates","role":"relates to"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Critical"],"valueId":["Critical"],"color":{"bg":"#ffc8ea","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Bug"],"valueId":["Bug"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Verified"],"valueId":["Verified"],"color":{"bg":"#409600","fg":"#fff"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"jsnead","fullName":"Jerry Snead"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2017 12 29"],"valueId":["2017 12 29"],"color":null},{"name":"attachments","value":[{"value":"control.log","id":"70-5934","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/control.log?file=70-5934&c=true"},{"value":"16 Color Raster.pdf","id":"70-5935","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/16%20Color%20Raster.pdf?file=70-5935&c=true"},{"value":"001.png","id":"70-5936","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/001.png?file=70-5936&c=true"},{"value":"002.png","id":"70-5937","url":"http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/_persistent/002.png?file=70-5937&c=true"}]}],"comment":[{"id":"69-11803","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Jerry Snead, Should I assume until told otherwise that you have all of the extra USB hubs daisychained between the PC and the laser system?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513967773827,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11804","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Tim Crews Correct. I have three USB hubs inline between the USB from the XLS and the NUC.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513968081632,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11806","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
After importing the job, it looks like you changed the raster stroke option. Once you started the job, the software should set that value as the "reference" value. Instead, when you resumed the job, it still thought the raster stroke option was changed, and insisted on restarting the job.

Besides that, it absolutely should not take three tries to pause the job. I'll add a note to JUB-730 indicating that you are still running into this problem.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513969609685,"updated":1513967773819,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11837","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I fixed this. To verify, I suggest:
  • Import the 16-color raster job.
  • Before running the job, change the raster margin setting.
  • Run the job. The raster margin setting that you selected before running the job should be stored as the "reference" raster setting, not the raster margin setting that was in effect just after you imported the job.
  • Pause the job.
  • Resume the job. It should resume without telling you that the job needs to be restarted. That's because your current raster margin settings are the same as they were when you started the job.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1514500462752,"updated":1513969609680,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11878","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Cannot check this one right now:
1. Black is not being imported (ST-256)
2. Unable to change available colors (14 in available, blue in db vector mark) to DB Raster (JUB-784)
3. If custom raster is attempted, the laser settings will not be held (JUB-786)

Currently no way to run the 16 color raster job at this juncture.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1514928643365,"updated":1514928879733,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11925","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Verified as fixed with Windows Jubilee. Unable to check in Linux (JUB-794) - will check Linux when that bug is fixed and then mark this bug as verified fixed overall.

Am assigning to myself as reminder to check this when JUB-794 is fixed.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1515084722108,"updated":1514928643360,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11952","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-242","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Due to all of the critical linux jubilee issues it is pretty hard to set up a job to test this in Linux. I was able to finally import the bear.pdf and test this out. Verified fixed on Linux Jubilee as well.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1515101216771,"updated":1515084722101,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-230","entityId":"64-7200","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"230"},{"name":"summary","value":"Air will not stay on."},{"name":"description","value":"
@ about 10:18, I tried several times to start the job. Got message that if one process was air assist then all must be. I went back and DB Raster (Black) was not set to air. I turned it on and pressed play and got same message. Air was turned off on this color again. Finally the system caught up I guess and the job started running.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1513358495869"},{"name":"updated","value":"1514926312383"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"resolved","value":"1514577320431"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"3"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-218","type":"Relates","role":"relates to"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Bug"],"valueId":["Bug"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["Verified"],"valueId":["Verified"],"color":{"bg":"#409600","fg":"#fff"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"abontrager","fullName":"Austyn Bontrager"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2017 12 29"],"valueId":["2017 12 29"],"color":null}],"comment":[{"id":"69-11725","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-230","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Control log too big to upload. Copy is here:
Engineering Drive:\Youtrack Issues\ST-230 Air will not stay on
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513358724723,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11726","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-230","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Jerry Snead, I think we have enough log data now to debug this problem; Austyn Bontrager has a potential fix in the works. It certainly does look like this issue is just another occurrence of the same problem.

If our theory is correct, as a workaround, restarting Jubilee should speed things back up for a while.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1513359184349,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-11871","author":"jsnead","authorFullName":"Jerry Snead","issueId":"ST-230","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I believe this issue is fixed and a separate issue from JUB-785 & JUB-786. Toggling to verified fixed.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1514926312384,"updated":1513358724707,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}]

[{"id":"ST-720","entityId":"64-9204","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"720"},{"name":"summary","value":"Store laser system-specific kinematic parameters on the laser system SD card"},{"name":"description","value":"
Because of ST-131, it is highly desirable to stop using rapidjson to serialize motion planning configuration parameters (including laser system-specific kinematic parameters) to/from disk. (The bogus error-handling approach adopted by this library in the name of performance can cause application termination if we try to access a JSON field that doesn't exist.)

My first proposed solution was to keep using JSON, but to use a different library to do it. This would require changing every line of code that currently accesses a JSON field.

But if we're going to touch every line of this code anyway, I think this is a good time to address several other technical issues with the way the kinematic parameters are stored.

First of all, JSON is not an ideal way to access this highly-structured data. Although JSON is meant to be human readable, the motion planning configuration JSON file is so deeply nested and large that it is basically impossible to navigate. Instead, I had to create a graphical user interface to manage the content of this file (the so-called "Planning GUI"). This file is essentially being treated as if it was not human readable.

Second, the laser system-specific kinematic parameters for all laser systems are stored in a single JSON file. We extract the correct parameters for the currently-attached laser system by looking up that laser system's model number in the file. This is one of the few remaining places in the control service code that relies on the concept of a "model". We have a system-wide design goal of eliminating the "model" concept. Instead, parameters that are specific to a laser system should be stored on that laser system's SD card, then accessed by the control service when the laser system is connected. This is how we handle the MachineConfiguration class, for example. The MachineConfiguration class is backed by data stored in the file DEVCAPS.INI on the laser system SD card.

The INI file format would be an even worse format than JSON for storing motion planning configuration parameters, because INI files can only support up to two levels of organization. So I am sure I don't want to store these parameters in DEVCAPS.INI or any other INI file. The INI format was a good choice for DEVCAPS.INI because the ULTRA CPU firmware needed to access values from this file, and it did not take much program space to include an INI file parser in the ULTRA CPU firmware. But the ULTRA CPU firmware doesn't need to know anything about the motion planning parameters. The motion planning parameter file can be treated as a black box by the ULTRA CPU firmware.

I think it would be worth some time to investigate the advantages of storing the kinematic parameters in a relational database, with proper tables and queries. Do not be concerned that this would turn into a task anywhere near as large as the DB Server (now called the Materials service). The kinematic parameters would likely be stored in three or four simple tables, and they would be accessed with just a couple of queries.

If that doesn't pan out, we can always fall back to storing the parameters in the Boost.Serialization format, as I have proposed for PrintParams and ImportOptions.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1533928118241"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535729441404"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"10"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-131","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["To be discussed"],"valueId":["To be discussed"],"color":{"bg":"#ce6700","fg":"#fff"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[{"id":"69-16528","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Unlike the other tasks that are children of ST-131, it would be nice to complete this task before any ULTRA systems are shipped, since it would entail storing a file on the ULTRA system SD card. However, even if we didn't complete this task before initial release, we could arrange for an updated control service to create this file on-the-fly and store it to the SD card after the fact.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1533928289780,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17108","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
As David Richter pointed out in http://youtrack.intranet.ulsinc.com/issue/ST-711#comment=69-17105, if we do decide to go with a database, we will probably need to develop a GUI front end for entering and modifying this data. (Although we've been getting by hand-editing our materials database for a couple of years now.)

Learning from our past mistakes, we should certainly use a cross-platform GUI framework for that application. The Camera Development GUI already uses Qt, so we have already taken on that dependency. I have used this application on both Windows and Linux, so the cross-platform part definitely works. Also, we already know have expertise with SOCI for C++ database access.

Because of the time constraints I mentioned in my 8/10 note, I propose that Tyler McLachlan start looking into this as soon as he wraps up ST-716.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535038856728,"updated":1533928289765,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17250","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Tyler McLachlan and I reviewed the affected parameters. On closer inspection, there are fewer laser system-dependent variables than I originally thought. I think a database might be a heavier weight solution than is warranted by the very small amount of data.

The "selector" values are:
  • Model name
  • Vector acceleration (0, 50, or 100)
  • Raster acceleration (0, 50, or 100)
  • X axis configuration
  • Y or R axis configuration
  • Pen state (pen up vector, pen down vector, raster)

Here are the fields of MotionPlanningConfig.json that depend on these selectors. The top level selector for all of them is Model name, which will be eliminated. Only the values that are appropriate for the laser system will be stored on that laser system's SD card.

  • For each axis
    • Minimum value, maximum value, field margin, and resolution. These are already redundant with values in DEVCAPS.INI (ST-767)
  • For each axis, for each axis configuration
    • Feed forward parameters (7 numbers, not used anywhere)
    • Servo parameters (10 numbers, not used anywhere)
  • For each quality
    • FPGA parameters (four numbers, not used anywhere)
  • For each quality, for each pen state
    • Maximum tangential velocity
  • For each axis, for each configuration, for each quality, for each pen state
    • Maximum axial velocity
    • Maximum axial acceleration
    • Maximum axial jerk

Taking away the parameters that are already available in DEVCAPS.INI and parameters that have never been used, the list is very short. They are restricted to kinematic limits:

  • For each quality, for each pen state
    • Maximum tangential velocity
  • For each axis, for each configuration, for each quality, for each pen state
    • Maximum axial velocity
    • Maximum axial acceleration
    • Maximum axial jerk

As mentioned in my opening note, the technical difficulty with storing these values in DEVCAPS.INI is that INI files only provide two levels of organization. INI files have sections, delimited by [ ] brackets. Within each section, they have a list of key/value pairs. But the parameters listed above are sometimes functions of as many as four variables (e.g. axis : configuration : quality : pen state). It would be possible, but clunky, to represent all four variables in a single section name, e.g.

[x : traveling exhaust : pen up vector : 50]

I would prefer to find some representation that makes it easy to tell if we have left out any necessary combinations, or specified illegal combinations. (For example, the valid axis configurations are different for each axis.) Also, even though there are only four input variables, there are 54 legal combinations of those four input variables, so the resulting INI file still might end up being almost as difficult to navigate and browse as the current JSON file:


[x : standard : pen up vector : 0]
[x : standard : pen up vector : 50]
[x : standard : pen up vector : 100]
-------------------------
[x : standard : pen down vector : 0]
[x : standard : pen down vector : 50]
[x : standard : pen down vector : 100]
-------------------------
[x : standard : raster: 0]
[x : standard : raster : 50]
[x : standard : raster : 100]
-----------------------------------------------
[x : multi-wave : pen up vector : 0]
[x : multi-wave : pen up vector : 50]
[x : multi-wave : pen up vector : 100]
-------------------------
[x : multi-wave : pen down vector : 0]
[x : multi-wave : pen down vector : 50]
[x : multi-wave : pen down vector : 100]
-------------------------
[x : multi-wave : raster: 0]
[x : multi-wave : raster : 50]
[x : multi-wave : raster : 100]
==================================================
[y : standard : pen up vector : 0]
[y : standard : pen up vector : 50]
[y : standard : pen up vector : 100]
-------------------------
[y : standard : pen down vector : 0]
[y : standard : pen down vector : 50]
[y : standard : pen down vector : 100]
-------------------------
[y : standard : raster: 0]
[y : standard : raster : 50]
[y : standard : raster : 100]
-----------------------------------------------

[y : traveling exhaust : pen up vector : 50]
[y : traveling exhaust : pen up vector : 100]
----------------------------------
[y : traveling exhaust : pen down vector : 0]
[y : traveling exhaust : pen down vector : 50]
[y : traveling exhaust : pen down vector : 100]
----------------------------------
[y : traveling exhaust : raster: 0]
[y : traveling exhaust : raster : 50]
[y : traveling exhaust : raster : 100]
-----------------------------------------------
[y : superspeed : pen up vector : 0]
[y : superspeed : pen up vector : 50]
[y : superspeed : pen up vector : 100]
----------------------------------
[y : superspeed : pen down vector : 0]
[y : superspeed : pen down vector : 50]
[y : superspeed : pen down vector : 100]
----------------------------------
[y : superspeed : raster: 0]
[y : superspeed : raster : 50]
[y : superspeed : raster : 100]
==================================================
[r : standard : pen up vector : 0]
[r : standard : pen up vector : 50]
[r : standard : pen up vector : 100]
-------------------------
[r : standard : pen down vector : 0]
[r : standard : pen down vector : 50]

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535374592092,"updated":1535379315715,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17253","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
David Richter, no matter what representation we choose for these 54 sets of kinematic parameters (JSON file, INI file, relational database, or something else), I assume that there will be a library of kinematics files somewhere. How will this library be organized? On what basis will manufacturing personnel select a file from that library to copy to the laser system's SD card?

The reason I ask is, one of the best, most future-proof, readable, and maintainable ways to represent the above information would be as a data structure in the control service code, instead of in an external file that is accessed by the code. If the code contained the entire "library" of kinematic limits, it would just need some criterion to select the correct limits set – presumably the same criterion that a manufacturing person would have used to select the SD card file.

In that case, maybe DEVCAPS.INI just needs a unique way to specify a selector value, which would then be used by the control service to look up the appropriate kinematic limits. I know this sounds an awful lot like a "model number" – the very concept we're trying to eliminate. But it need not be a model number. It could be a descriptive string, for example. Or maybe there is some other inherent, essential, descriptive trait of a laser system that would be more suitable as a basis for selection of kinematic limits instead of an identifier string.

Our other question is about what we might expect to vary in the field or in the future. Can owners of our laser systems reconfigure them in the field to the extent that a new set of kinematic parameters would apply to that system? What would trigger the use of new kinematic parameters? Even more fundamentally, currently we support three x-axis configurations and two y-axis configurations. Is it possible that ULS will someday invent entirely new axis configurations that our code currently knows nothing about? How should those be accommodated?

Until we know more about the data will be used, I don't think we can make a good decision about how to represent it.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535380837473,"updated":1535374592076,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17314","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Thinking on this further, I am still sure that we do not want to represent this data in an INI format. It is just too unnatural to represent four levels of organization in a two-level file format.

If the data is going to be represented as a file that can be stored on the laser system's SD card (which will not necessarily be the case, depending on David's answers to yesterday's questions), I still think that JSON is the right way to go. However, we can significantly simplify the schema for that JSON file compared to MotionPlanningConfig.json now that this file has had all of its unused data stripped out. [I made some quirky decisions when I designed the original format for reasons that aren't obvious now; I repent of them.]

Here is a possible JSON representation for the kinematic limits for a given laser system. It is simply a four-level-deep nested structure, with the levels appearing in the order pen state -> optimization -> axis -> axis configuration. I think this representation has the following advantages:
  • It is fairly self-descriptive
  • It is directly human editable (especially if the human has an outlining text editor). We need not develop a cross-platform graphical user interface to maintain it.
  • I estimate that the C++ JSON parsing code for this format would be less than 20 lines (compared to the 500 lines currently found in LoadConfigurationFromJSON).

The numeric 0.0 values are just place-holders, of course.

{
  "pen up vector": {
    "optimize quality": {
      "tvmax": 0.0,
      "x axis": {
        "standard configuration": {
          "vmax": 0.0,
          "amax": 0.0,
          "jmax": 0.0
        },

          "amax": 0.0,
          "jmax": 0.0

          "jmax": 0.0

","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535460849345,"updated":1535465825848,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17323","author":"drichter","authorFullName":"David Richter","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I have no preference for the data format. JSON seems like a reasonable choice to me for the reasons Tim Crews mentions.

I see, however, no reason to store that information on the SD card. I assume that it would make it more difficult to update in the field if there were issues - maybe not. Perhaps we could encrypt the JSON file or otherwise obfuscate to make it less readable once deployed?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535474630258,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17327","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I see, however, no reason to store that information on the SD card.


This is the heart of the matter. We made a philosophically-based decision to store DEVCAPS.INI on the SD card, with the idea that each system should describe its own capabilities instead of advertising its "model number" and letting the control service determine look up its capabilities. I was assuming that this same design philosophy would apply to the kinematic parameters.

If this data is stored on the same filesystem as the control service, the problem remains that the control service can potentially connect to many different kinds of laser systems. If the control service has a library of kinematic settings that are appropriate for different laser systems, how will those laser systems identify themselves? Are we back to using the model number for this purpose? My understanding was that we were trying to eliminate our reliance on model numbers.

I am currently working on an epic response to an e-mail from Dave Schultz that raises similar questions, so I will defer the rest of my discussion to that e-mail.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535475340171,"updated":1535460849329,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17369","author":"wvalentine","authorFullName":"Wendy Valentine","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
cc group on email
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535494954203,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17429","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Wendy Valentine, do you mean the softwareeng@ulsinc.com group?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535571753493,"updated":1535475340171,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17444","author":"wvalentine","authorFullName":"Wendy Valentine","issueId":"ST-720","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
It might have been easier on you since you copied most of the group :) I think you included all relevant individuals in the email except me.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535587746251,"updated":1535494954188,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-786","entityId":"64-9541","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"786"},{"name":"summary","value":"Find a way to get logger names and levels in the syslog-managed log file"},{"name":"description","value":"
When the spdlog logger is configured to use the syslog log sink class, it discards the logger name, which does not appear in the resulting log file.

The logger names are a very important source of diagnostic information. I think it is worth the time to figure out some way, no matter how ugly it may be, to get the logger names into the syslog file.

We are already using the spdlog-provided mechanism for specifying the content of every log line, and we are telling it to include the logger name. spdlog must have code that bypasses this configuration when using the syslog sink. Since we don't want to change the spdlog code itself, we will probably have to do something ugly like explicitly prepending the logger name to the log string. I hope there is another hook in the spdlog API that gives us an opportunity to do so.


Edit: Now that I have the syslog destination running on my machine, I see that the log level also does not appear in the log file. If anything, this is even more important than the logger name. I really need both of them to appear in the log file.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1535640102924"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535729428924"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"0"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Feature"],"valueId":["Feature"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-718","entityId":"64-9200","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"718"},{"name":"summary","value":"Move many parameters from MotionPlanningConfig.json to plain old C++ constants in the code"},{"name":"description","value":"
Because of ST-131, it is highly desirable to stop using rapidjson to serialize motion planning configuration parameters to/from disk. (The bogus error-handling approach adopted by this library in the name of performance can cause application termination if we try to access a JSON field that doesn't exist.)

My first proposed solution was to keep using JSON, but to use a different library to do it. This would require changing every line of code that currently accesses a JSON field.

But if we're going to touch every line of this code anyway, I think now is a good time to address the fact that many of the values currently stored in MotionPlanningConfig.json are really not worth having in a JSON file in the first place. These are global constants that hardly ever change – maybe two or three of these constants have changed in the last four years. These constants would be far easier to maintain if they were simply declared as constants directly in the C++ code.

Besides that, all of these values are currently stored in an enormous catch-all struct generically named "Configuration". This is not a good design. If we are going to change these values to C++ constants, those constants should be directly located in the classes that use them.

This applies to all of the following JSON values:
  "global options": {
    "servo update rate": 0.0001,
    "minimum fpga pulse duration": 4E-08,
    "number of axes": 2,
    "nurbs degree": 3,
    "artwork sampler": {
      "sampling resolution": 0.001
    },
    "path construction": {
      "max cornering error": 0.005,
      "max point removal distance": 0.003,
      "line length leveling factor": 5.0,
      "max pen up near projection distance": 0.0,
      "max pen up far projection distance": 0.0,
      "raster line margin": 0.025,
      "endpoint snap distance": 0.001,
      "kerf compensation nurbs segment length": 0.001,
      "kerf compensation nurbs segment length tolerance factor": 0.316,
      "nurbs metrics segment length": 0.01,
      "nurbs metrics segment length tolerance factor": 0.316
    },
    "path optimization": {
      "nearest neighbor y motion penalty factor": 3.0
    },
    "beudaert planner": {
      "root finding tolerance absolute": 1E-16,
      "constraint box tolerance absolute": 1E-10,
      "duplicate intersection tolerance absolute": 1E-10,
      "tangential velocity tolerance absolute": 1E-10,
      "max tangential velocity iterations": 50,
      "num u min steps on backtrack": 20,
      "max crawl steps per try": 1,
      "crawl delta u divider": 1000000.0,
      "minimum knots to trigger subdivision": 100,
      "extrema finding delta u sub-sampling factor": 500,
      "extrema finding max samples per inch": 5000,
      "search bounds delta u sub-sampling factor": 50,
      "search bounds max samples per inch": 5000,
      "vector limit relaxation velocity threshold": 0.0,
      "vector limit relaxation acceleration multiplier": 1.0,
      "vector limit relaxation jerk multiplier": 4.0,
      "raster limit relaxation line length threshold": 0.0,
      "raster limit relaxation acceleration multiplier": 2.0,
      "raster limit relaxation jerk multiplier": 4.0
    },
    "available motion up-samplers": [
      "u domain, linear",
      "Cartesian domain, linear",
      "u domain, Akima",
      "Cartesian domain, Akima"
    ],
    "selected motion up-sampler": "Cartesian domain, linear",
    "available feed-forward up-samplers": [
      "Cartesian domain, linear",
      "Cartesian domain, Akima"
    ],
    "selected feed-forward up-sampler": "Cartesian domain, linear",
    "pulse compensator": {
      "enabled": true,
      "start time tmax": 1.4E-05,
      "start time tlagmax": 2.72E-05,
      "start time b2": 49000000.0,
      "start time b3": 410000000000.0,
      "pulse width tlagmax": 1.8E-05,
      "pulse width b2": 39130000.0,
      "pulse width b3": 36670000000.0
    },
    "motion planning gui settings do not use": {
      "vector sorting mode": "inner outer",
      "path optimization mode": "nearest neighbor",
      "kerf width compensation mode": "none",
      "kerf width": 0.001,
      "rotary enabled": false,
      "rotary radius": 2.0,
      "pulse compensator laser delay time 0": 0.0,
      "pulse compensator laser delay time 1": 0.0,
      "pulse compensator laser delay time 2": 0.0,
      "artwork x1": 0.0,
      "artwork y1": 0.0,
      "artwork x2": 1.0,
      "artwork y2": 0.0,
      "artwork x3": 0.0,
      "artwork y3": 1.0,
      "artwork x4": 1.0,
      "artwork y4": 1.0,
      "fiducial x1": 0.0,
      "fiducial y1": 0.0,
      "fiducial x2": 1.0,
      "fiducial y2": 0.0,
      "fiducial x3": 0.0,
      "fiducial y3": 1.0,
      "fiducial x4": 1.0,
      "fiducial y4": 1.0,
      "pierce on pen down": false,
      "drill pulse period laser 1": 0.001,
      "drill pulse period laser 2": 0.003,
      "drill pulse period laser 3": 0.005,
      "drill duty cycle laser 1": 20,
      "drill duty cycle laser 2": 30,
      "drill duty cycle laser 3": 40,
      "drill dwell time laser 1": 0.02,
      "drill dwell time laser 2": 0.03,
      "drill dwell time laser 3": 0.04
    }
  },

I have not assigned this issue to the current sprint because it is not strictly necessary before our initial software release. Tyler is working on this task on an SVN branch that will have no effect on the trunk software or the initial released software unless it gets done in time, and the management decides to incorporate this feature into the initial release.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1533926436566"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535636650622"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"1"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-131","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[{"id":"69-17446","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-718","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Tyler McLachlan, I have partially completed this task; I removed all of the "global options" from the MotionPlanningConfig.json file. They are now only represented as C++ constants in the Configuration class, with the same values that used to be in the JSON file. It is easy to tell which options were affected – they are identified as "const" members of the Configuration class.

The only data that remains in MotionPlanningConfig.json is kinematic parameters, the subject of ST-720.

I still think a second refactoring would be nice here. I think most (or probably all) of these constants in the Configuration class are actually only used by one other class. Those constants should be moved to the class that uses them. For classes which formerly took a Configuration reference in their constructor, if their only use of that Configuration reference was to access these constants, remove the Configuration dependency from the class.

There are still seven data members of the Configuration class that are not const. Those are changeable at run-time. They are mostly exposed to the user as job settings. I think once we have got all the extraneous stuff out of the Configuration class, it may become pretty obvious that the Configuration class has entirely outlived its purpose. The remaining variables should probably be managed entirely as fields of PrintSettings/PrintParams and passed around as individual parameters to the places that need them.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535636650622,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-131","entityId":"64-6173","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"131"},{"name":"summary","value":"All of our JSON parsing code is using an invalid error-handling approach"},{"name":"description","value":"
The rapidjson library by design does not use C++ exceptions. This is one of the ways that it achieves its very fast performance. We do not particularly need its very fast performance – UlsControl typically parses a JSON file every couple of minutes, and the difference between 10ms and 100ms to parse such a file is totally irrelevant. I would prefer to use a library that throws meaningful exceptions when error conditions occur, at the expense of somewhat slower performance.

I was not really focused on that issue when I first started writing code that used rapidjson. At some point I discovered that rapidjson was using assert() calls to check for various error conditions – for example, trying to access a field that does not exist in the JSON document. I very strongly believe that this is an inappropriate use of assert(). Assert() is meant to enforce global invariants whose violation is an indication of a coding error. Assert() is compiled away to nothing in release builds. This is an atrocious way to handle run-time errors.

Apparently the authors of rapidjson think that the coding error is the fault of the user of their library; the calling code should know better than to try to access a field that doesn't exist.

Anyway, it appears that my decision at the time was to simply translate the assert() calls into throws of C++ exceptions using the RAPIDJSON_ASSERT macro. Then I wrote nice simple JSON parsing code (for example, UlsHttpTransition.cpp, LoadPrintSettingsFromJSON) that had a single try/catch around the whole function.

But now we are using more modern compilers that are detecting some coding errors that weren't being detected two years ago. In particular, both Clang and gcc are emitting compiler warnings indicating that RAPIDJSON_ASSERT (which is throwing an exception) is being used in rapidjson functions that are labelled "noexcept". The result will be that these exceptions will not be propagated; they will immediately result in a call to std::terminate, which will crash the application.

So I have two choices:
  • Use a different JSON parsing library that uses C++ exceptions to indicate error conditions like this.
  • Change all of our JSON parsing code to not use operator[] to access fields, but instead explicitly check for the presence of each field before accessing it.

Unfortunately in both cases, there are hundreds if not thousands of JSON field accesses in our code. This will be a lot of work. But it is necessary; currently UlsControl will immediately crash if we feed it a JSON document that is missing expected fields.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1503069454916"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535551559473"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"4"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-716","type":"Subtask","role":"parent for"},{"value":"ST-718","type":"Subtask","role":"parent for"},{"value":"ST-719","type":"Subtask","role":"parent for"},{"value":"ST-720","type":"Subtask","role":"parent for"},{"value":"ST-767","type":"Subtask","role":"parent for"},{"value":"ST-778","type":"Subtask","role":"parent for"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Feature"],"valueId":["Feature"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[{"id":"69-9732","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-131","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I spent some time this weekend investigating how much work it will be to fix this. It will be a lot. No matter how we do it, it will involve touching every line of code that accesses a field in a JSON file. There are thousands of such lines.

I created a feature branch branches/tcrews/JsonErrors. In that branch, I deleted rapidjson and replaced it with https://github.com/nlohmann/json. This looks like a very nice C++ JSON library.

I started working my way through the UlsCommon project, fixing up each line of JSON code. After a total of about three hours of work, I estimate I was less than halfway done just with that project. I think it would take ten to twenty more hours of work to finish this task. I have left that branch in its partially-completed state, but I will not continue working on it unless directed by the management.

In the meantime, if DBServer or UlsControl [edit: or UILauncher] tries to access a JSON file that is missing a field, the application will crash. This is not quite the major issue that it sounds like because our own software creates those JSON files, and it does not create them with missing fields. [Edit: Except during maintenance, or when we are transitioning between different JSON formats.] But if a user hand-edited one of our JSON files, that could cause a crash. Users shouldn't do that.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1503336174098,"updated":1507038772507,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-14748","author":"ajones","authorFullName":"Aaron Jones","issueId":"ST-131","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
Change all of our JSON parsing code to not use operator[] to access fields, but instead explicitly check for the presence of each field before accessing it.


I haven't looked at the code yet, but is there any chance we could write a clever awk or sed script to modify the code to check for presence before accessing a field?
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1527607607741,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-14749","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-131","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
When I made the changes on branches/tcrews/JsonErrors, I used regular expression search and replace as much as possible within my IDE. I preferred this to sed/awk because it allowed me to be more targeted with the regions of code being affected, and also allowed me to account for minor variations in different code modules.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1527611016821,"updated":1503336174089,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-16527","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-131","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I removed this issue from the current sprint, even though Tyler is currently working on it, because it is not strictly necessary before our initial software release. Tyler is working on this feature on an SVN branch that will have no effect on the trunk software or the initial released software unless it gets done in time, and the management decides to incorporate this feature into the initial release.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1533926897097,"updated":1527611016821,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-716","entityId":"64-9196","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"716"},{"name":"summary","value":"Serialize PrintParams to/from disk using Boost.Serialization instead of JSON"},{"name":"description","value":"
Because of ST-131, it is highly desirable to stop using rapidjson to serialize PrintParams to/from disk. (The bogus error-handling approach adopted by this library in the name of performance can cause application termination if we try to access a JSON field that doesn't exist.)

My first proposed solution was to keep using JSON, but to use a different library to do it. This would require changing every line of code that currently access a JSON field.

But if we're going to touch every line of this code anyway, it makes more sense to use Boost.Serialization instead of any JSON library. JSON is suitable as a configuration file format that is intended to be human-edited. But for PrintParams, we are purely using it as a serialization format. Boost.Serialization, as indicated by its name, was tailor-made for serialization. It is much easier to write serialization code with Boost.Serialization than with any JSON library. The resulting code is far more readable and maintainable. I am certain that it will be less work to change our PrintParams serialization to use Boost.Serialization than it would be to update all of our PrintParams JSON code, and the end result will be better.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1533925681506"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535495562250"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"2"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-131","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[{"id":"69-16523","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-716","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
I have not assigned this issue to the current sprint, even though Tyler is currently working on it, because it is not strictly necessary before our initial software release. Tyler is working on this task on an SVN branch that will have no effect on the trunk software or the initial released software unless it gets done in time, and the management decides to incorporate this feature into the initial release.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1533925895446,"updated":null,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]},{"id":"69-17195","author":"tcrews","authorFullName":"Tim Crews","issueId":"ST-716","parentId":null,"deleted":false,"jiraId":null,"text":"
These changes have been committed to trunk, except for the "instead of" part. For the time being, the PrintParams are serialized using Boost.Serialization in addition to JSON. We have added validation code that loads the PrintParams from both JSON and Boost.Serialization and compares the results. If it finds any mismatches, it sends an error message to the LSM with instructions to send the corresponding files to Tyler so he can debug the issue.

If we go a week or so without encountering any of these errors, we can take the next step of removing the JSON serialization code and JSON files.
","shownForIssueAuthor":false,"created":1535134767264,"updated":1533925895430,"permittedGroup":null,"replies":[]}],"tag":[]}, {"id":"ST-719","entityId":"64-9202","jiraId":null,"field":[{"name":"projectShortName","value":"ST"},{"name":"numberInProject","value":"719"},{"name":"summary","value":"Serialize ImportOptions to/from disk using Boost.Serialization instead of JSON"},{"name":"description","value":"
Because of ST-131, it is highly desirable to stop using rapidjson to serialize ImportOptions to/from disk. (The bogus error-handling approach adopted by this library in the name of performance can cause application termination if we try to access a JSON field that doesn't exist.)

My first proposed solution was to keep using JSON, but to use a different library to do it. This would require changing every line of code that currently accesses a JSON field.

But if we're going to touch every line of this code anyway, it makes more sense to use Boost.Serialization instead of any JSON library. JSON is suitable as a configuration file format that is intended to be human-edited. But for ImportOptions, we are purely using it as a serialization format. Boost.Serialization, as indicated by its name, was tailor-made for serialization. It is much easier to write serialization code with Boost.Serialization than with any JSON library. The resulting code is far more readable and maintainable.

ImportOptions only consists of three or four values, so this task will be trivial.
"},{"name":"created","value":"1533926606654"},{"name":"updated","value":"1535495552719"},{"name":"updaterName","value":"jsnead"},{"name":"updaterFullName","value":"Jerry Snead"},{"name":"reporterName","value":"tcrews"},{"name":"reporterFullName","value":"Tim Crews"},{"name":"commentsCount","value":"0"},{"name":"votes","value":"0"},{"name":"links","value":[{"value":"ST-131","type":"Subtask","role":"subtask of"}]},{"name":"Priority","value":["Normal"],"valueId":["Normal"],"color":{"bg":"#e6f6cf","fg":"#4da400"}},{"name":"Type","value":["Task"],"valueId":["Task"],"color":null},{"name":"State","value":["In Progress"],"valueId":["In Progress"],"color":{"bg":"#fed74a","fg":"#444"}},{"name":"Assignee","value":[{"value":"tmclachlan","fullName":"Tyler McLachlan"}]},{"name":"Milestone","value":["2018 08 24"],"valueId":["2018 08 24"],"color":null}],"comment":[],"tag":[]}]
